uni-hamburg.de";1;2;Behaviour research and therapy;57;2016;1;1;1;;17;0;;1;1;2;1;1;1;;20;;0;1;1;2;;2;;RMSSD;1;"In the intervention phase
column2: the procedure varied for the groups.

column1: The BF group received an introduction into the procedure and its
application for increasing HRV. We adapted the method from
Lehrer et al. (2000). The training consisted of two screens that were
shown for 10 min each. The first screen exhibited a breathing pacer
set at six breaths per min (4s inhale
that expanded and contracted with the participants' respiration.
The task was to breathe at the deep respiration rate in accordance
with the pacer. The second screen displayed the participants'
respiration and heart rate curves. The task was to continue deep
breathing and to synchronize both curves. The participants were
briefly trained in diaphragmatic breathing (e.g.
pursed lips) and received a short trial period to test the procedure
and clarify possible questions or difficulties";active control group;HRV;;6;;1;1;;;;;0.560;;;;;;;;2;81;0.573;;;;;29;27;28;;;1;2;1;1;2;2;1;;

column5: F.";lesliesherlin@mac.com;1;1;International Journal of Stress Management;27;2009;1;1;3;;64;20;1;1;1;2;1;1;1;Immediatly after the intervention;15;only 15 minutes;0;0;1;2;;1;;STAY- S state anxiety;2;"The HRV biofeedback device (the StressEraser; Helicor

column1: NY) an over-the-counter noninvasive biofeedback device that displays the
natural rise and fall of real-time pulse-by-pulse activity as a wave (RSA) on
the screen via an infrared finger sensor. Participants were instructed to slow
their breathing to a rate that is unique to them by inhaling until their HR
